metadata.title: Semi-hydrogenation of alkynes using Ru/TPPTS as a biphasic recyclable catalyst in ethylene glycol-toluene solvent system

Scheme 1 E and Z- selective semi-hydrogenation of alkynes using Ru/TPPTS as a biphasic and recyclable catalyst. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 Typical representation of separation and recyclability of catalyst in biphasic catalysis. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Recyclability study for the semi-hydrogenation of diphenylacetylene using Ru/TPPTS as biphasic and reusable catalyst. Table 5 Substrate study for semi-hydrogenation of terminal alkynes. a Table 5 a Reaction Conditions: alkyne (1 mmol), Ru3(CO)12 (0.01 mmol), TPPTS (0.04 mmol), CO/H2 (10 bar), EG-Toluene 1:1 (10 mL), 70 °C, 6 h, 600 rpm. Yield determined by GC. Semi-hydrogenation of alkynes using Ru/TPPTS as a biphasic recyclable catalyst in ethylene glycol-toluene solvent system Samadhan Ashok Jagtap Bhalchandra Mahadeo Bhanage ⁎ Department of Chemistry, Institute of Chemical Technology, Matunga, Mumbai, 400019, India Department of Chemistry Institute of Chemical Technology Matunga Mumbai 400019 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The chemoselective semi-hydrogenation of alkynes into E and Z-alkenes was studied by using Ru/TPPTS as a biphasic and recyclable catalyst in ethylene glycol-toluene solvent system. Current protocol is atom efficient and gives selectivity up to 98%. This protocol is alternative to the classical Lindlar catalyst (Pd/CaCO3) for Z-alkenes and also Birch reduction process (Li/Na/K in liq. NH3) used for the synthesis of E-alkenes. A variety of alkynes with different functional group can be tolerated efficiently transformed into corresponding E and Z alkenes. This catalytic system has been effectively recycled up to five consecutive cycles without appreciable loss in its activity and selectivity. Keywords Biphasic catalysis Recyclable Ruthenium Semi-hydrogenation TPPTS 1 Introduction Chemoselective synthesis of E and Z-olefins via semi-hydrogenation of alkynes is one of the valuable organic transformations in synthetic organic chemistry [1]. E and Z- olefins are fundamental building blocks used in the several pharmaceutical drug moieties, flavours, natural products and biological active compounds [2]. Styrene and its derivatives are used as a raw material for the synthesis of polystyrenes, synthetic rubbers and the various organic commodities [3]. Alkenes are used in many synthetic organic reactions such as Markovnikoffs addition, epoxidation, metathesis, ozonolysis, hydroboration, hydrogenation, hydroformylation and hydroamination reactions [4]. trans-Stilbene is highly valuable intermediate employed in dyes, fluorescent whitener, liquid crystals and organic light-emitting diodes [5]. Z-alkenes are present in many biologically and pharmaceutically active compounds and are produced in numerous bulk and fine chemical processes [6]. According to literature survey, a variety of transition metal catalysts Pd [7], Rh [8], Ru [9], Cu [10], Au [11], Ni [12] and Co [13] have been reported for the semi-hydrogenation of alkynes. Lindlar catalyst (Pd/CaCO3) is used as heterogeneous catalyst for Z-selective semi-hydrogenation of alkynes [14]. Despite the potential utility of Lindlar catalyst (Pd/CaCO3) treated with Pb(OAc)2 suffers from drawbacks such as use of poisonous lead (Pb) salt and use of excess quinoline to control the over-hydrogenation, which also limits its substrate scope and selectivity. The Birch-type reduction of alkynes by alkali metals (Li, Na) in liquid ammonia is conventional and powerful method for the synthesis of E-alkenes [15]. Birch reduction also have some limitations, as it requires the stoichiometric amount of a base and harsh reductive reaction conditions along with the use of alkali metals in liquid ammonia. This reagent was incompatible with functionalized alkynes containing base-labile or reducible moieties. Aqueous biphasic organometallic catalysis is a greener method for the synthesis of organic chemicals [16]. The novel synthesis of sodium salt of trisulfonated triphenylphosphine (TPPTS) in 1974 helped to the development of the field of aqueous biphasic systems [17]. Ruhrchemie and Rhone-Poulenc commercialized the Rh-TPPTS based aqueous biphasic catalytic system in 1984 for the hydroformylation of propene [18]. Recently, we have reported the Rh-TPPTS catalyzed aqueous biphasic hydroformylation of biorenewable eugenol [19]. TPPTS ligand is highly robust and reusable using biphasic catalysis due to its highly solubility in water as well as it can interact with hydrophilic organic solvents like ethylene glycol [20]. We have recently reported efficient semi-hydrogenation of alkynes catalyzed by rhodium in the presence of various phosphine ligands [8(b)]. In spite of the good activity and selectivity of the catalyst used in this protocol was the homogeneous in nature and cannot be recycled. In view of these drawbacks, the development biphasic catalytic system for this reaction is highly desirable for recyclability of expensive metal catalyst. In 2011, Hua [21] and co-workers reported ruthenium catalysed stereo-divergent transfer semi-hydrogenation using DMF and water as a hydrogen source. The use of acetic acid and trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) as additives is one of the drawbacks of this protocol. Recently, Rafał [22] et. al reported homogeneous ruthenium catalyzed olefin metathesis for E and Z selective semi-hydrogenation of alkynes. In 2013, Niu [23] et al. described the recyclable ruthenium nanoparticles as catalysts for the semi-hydrogenation of alkynes using thermo regulated PEG as biphasic system. This catalyst works only for terminal alkynes. Considering all above these issues; highly efficient, recyclable, additive free and co-catalyst free catalytic system is highly desirable. Herein, we report the Ru-TPPTS as a biphasic and reusable catalyst for the selective E and Z semi-hydrogenation of alkynes in ethylene glycol-toluene as a solvent system under syngas and molecular hydrogen (Scheme 1 ). Syngas containing carbon monoxide acts as a mild poison which inhibits the over-hydrogenation and provides selectively towards Z-alkenes as a major product by the syn addition of hydrogen [7(a)]. Selective formation of E product formed may be due to the steric hindrance caused by p-cymene ligand used in ruthenium catalyst 1. The developed protocol tolerates wide range of internal as well as terminal alkynes which affords the respective alkenes with 85–98% selectivity. This catalytic system was reusable up to five recycles without affecting the activity and selectivity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods All the experiments were performed under nitrogen atmosphere by using 100 mL stainless steel autoclave purchased from M/s Amar Equipments Pvt. Ltd, Mumbai. All the chemicals e.g. alkynes, [RuCl2(p-cymene)]2, [Ru3(CO)12] and TPPTS were purchased from Sigma Aldrich and Alfa Aesar. All other reagents and solvents (Ethylene glycol and Toluene) were purchased form Sigma Aldrich, S.D. Fine and commercial suppliers in Mumbai Area. The reagents of analytical grade were used without further purification. Syngas (CO and H2 in the 1:1 ratio) with a purity of 99.9%, was procured from Rakhangi Gases Ltd, Mumbai, India. The progress of reaction was monitored by using PerkinElmer Clarus 400 gas chromatograph equipped with flame ionization detector using capillary column (Elite-1, 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 m). GCMS-QP 2010 instrument (Rtx-17, 30 m × F5 mm ID, film thickness (df) = 0.25 m) was used for the mass analysis of the products. Organic compounds (products) were purified by column chromatography on silica (120–200 mesh). Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were taken on Bruker in CDCl3 solvent (1H, 400 MHz; 13C, 100 MHz) spectrometer using tetramethylsilane (1 H) as an internal standard. Chemical shifts values are reported in parts per million (δ) relative to tetramethylsilane as an internal standard. The J (coupling constant) values were described in Hz. Splitting patterns of proton are denoted as s (singlet), d (doublet), t (triplet) and m (multiplet). Products were assured by the comparison of their GC, GC–MS, 1H and 13C NMR spectra with those of authentic data. 2.2 Typical experimental procedure for the synthesis of alkenes via semi-hydrogenation of alkynes All the chemicals were added to a high pressure reaction using two different methods. For method A: alkyne (0.5 mmol), [RuCl2(p-cymene)]2 (0.02 mmol), TPPTS (0.08 mmol), in a 10 mL biphase solvent (5 mL Toluene + 5 mL Ethylene glycol) were taken. The reactor was flushed three times with nitrogen, then pressurized with 5 bar of H2 and heated at 80 °C with constant stirring (600 rpm) for 8 h. For method B: alkyne (0.5 mmol), Ru3(CO)12 (0.02 mmol), TPPTS (0.08 mmol), Solvent (5 mL Toluene + 5 mL Ethylene glycol) syngas (10 bar) were added to the reaction. After the completion of reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature and remaining gas vented out carefully. The obtained biphasic mixture was separated using simple decantation process. The separated organic product from biphasic solution was dried over sodium sulfate to remove moisture if present. The organic product was collected for purification and then it is subjected for further analysis such as GC, GC–MS, 1H & 13C NMR and matched with those of authentic data. 2.3 Typical experimental procedure for recycling of Ru-PPTS catalyst In the catalyst recycling experiments, the Ru-TPPTS catalyst system was easily separated from the reaction mixture by simple phase separation as shown in Fig. 1 . The biphasic solution has two phases, the upper phase of toluene containing reactant and product while lower phase of ethylene glycol contains Ru-TPPTS catalyst. The separated Ru-TPPTS catalyst in ethylene glycol was recovered and used for the next reaction cycle. 3 Results and discussion The semi-hydrogenation of diphenylacetylene (DPA) was tested as a model reaction to estimate the feasibility of present catalytic system in toluene-ethylene glycol biphasic solvent at 80 °C for 10 h. Various reaction parameters such as loading of ruthenium catalyst, the influence of syngas and hydrogen pressure, effect of reaction time and temperature, and effect of solvent were screened. The obtained results are summarized in Tables 1–3 . Various ruthenium precursors such as Ru3(CO)12, RuCl3.6H2O, [RuCl2(p-cymene)]2, [CpRu(COD)Cl], [Ru(COD)Cl2], Ru(PPh3)3Cl2, 10% Ru/C were tested as shown in Table 1. Among them Ru3(CO)12 and [RuCl2(p-cymene)]2 gives high conversion of 1a with admirable selectivity towards the formation of Z and E stilbene (2a) respectively (Table 1, entries 2 and 4). As we increase the loading of catalyst (Ru3CO12) from 0.02 mmol to 0.03 mmol then conversion increases significantly, but the hydrogenation increases and selectivity of 2a decreases (Table 1, entry 3). Furthermore, we studied [CpRu(COD)Cl], [Ru(COD)Cl2] and Ru(PPh3)3Cl2 catalyst precursors with TPPTS ligand, these catalysts were provided good conversion while moderate selectivity of 2a with inappropriate E and Z selectivity (Table 1, entries 5–7). In case of Ru(PPh3)3Cl2 catalyst with the addition of TPPTS ligand leads to the formation of Ru-TPPTS complex by ligand exchange method [16a, c]. We have also tested heterogeneous 5% Ru/C catalyst which provided good conversion; however it gives over-hydrogenation in the 65:35% selectivity for the products 2a:3a (Table 1, entry 8). The product (2a and 3a) was not formed without catalyst (Table 1, entry 9) and it indicates that the catalytic system is necessary for the semi-hydrogenation reaction. With the objective to increase Z-selectivity of 2a, we examined the optimization parameters for model reaction at 80 °C for 10 h in Ethylene glycol-Toluene as solvent system (Table 2). The reaction was carried out at 20 bar and 10 bar syngas pressure and it gave high conversion and excellent selectivity of Z-isomer i.e. 2a using 10 bar syngas pressure (Table 2, entries 1 and 2). Then we used 10 bar pressure by increasing the concentration of H2 gas with 1/2 ratio of CO/H2, 90% conversion obtained but it lead to over-hydrogenation product 3a (Table 2, entry 3). If we increase the concentration of CO gas with 2/1 ratio of CO/H2 then it provides less conversion and good Z-selectivity of 2a (Table 2, entry 4). The rate of over-hydrogenation increased due to the reaction carried out with 10 bar H2 gas (Table 2, entry 5). The reaction was not processed under 10 bar carbon monoxide pressure; it indicates that the hydrogen gas is responsible for the reaction (Table 2, entry 6). Furthermore, we investigated the effect of reaction time and temperature for the effective improvement of the reaction. During the investigation of reaction time we increase the reaction time up to 12 h, which resulted in over-hydrogenation product 3a (Table 2, entry 7). Then we reduced reaction time to 8 h and it was found as optimum reaction time to achieve high conversion as well as excellent Z-selectivity of 2a (Table 2, entry 8). Decreasing the reaction time up to 6 h lead to a significant decrease in the conversion and no significant change in Z-selectivity of 2a (Table 2, entry 9). Next, we tested the influence of reaction temperature from 60 °C to 100 °C and it was observed that conversion of 1a raise with increase in reaction temperature from 60 °C to 100 °C, but a slowly decrease in the Z-selectivity of 2a (Table 2, entries 8, 10–12). The temperature 80 °C was observed as an optimized reaction temperature for the reaction to get the outstanding Z-selectivity of product 2a (Table 2, entry 8). To increase the E selectivity of 2a, we used the [RuCl2(p-cymene)]2 catalyst with TPPTS ligand from the observation of entry 4 of Table 1. We studied the hydrogen pressure at 2 bar, 5 bar and 10 bar at 80 °C for 10 h. At 2 bar H2 pressure low conversion with good E selectivity of 2a was observed (Table 3, entry 1). High conversion (95%) and high E-selectivity of 2a was observed at 5 bar H2 gas (Table 3, entry 2). The rate of over-hydrogenation increased at 10 bar H2 pressure as a result 70% of 3a product was formed with high conversion 99% of 1a (Table 3, entry 3). Then. we studied influence of reaction time on progress of reaction, when reaction was carried out for 12 h time then the conversion was 100% but the E-selectivity of 2a was decreased (Table 3, entry 4). The reaction was carried out in 8 h then the conversion and E-selectivity of 2a was observed as an excellent, so the optimum time of reaction was 8 h (Table 3, entry 5). We reduced the reaction time to 6 h, then E-selectivity of 2a has no significant change, but the conversion decreases (Table 2, entry 6). Next we investigated the influence of temperature in the range from 60 °C to 100 °C to check the effective progress of reaction (Table 3, entries 5, 7–9). The reaction temperature of 80 °C was observed as optimum temperature to achieve the 97% conversion 95% selectivity of 2a with 98% selectivity of E isomer (Table 3, entry 5). Furthermore, the standard optimized reaction parameters were used for the wide substrate applicability of the present protocol. To our pleasure, aromatic as well as aliphatic internal alkynes were easily transformed into the respective E and Z-alkenes afforded 90–98% selectivity as shown in Table 4 . The alkyne 1a furnished 98% E-selectivity of 2a via method A while 97% Z-selectivity of 2a via method B. The aromatic internal alkynes 1b, 1c, 1d and 1e were transformed into corresponding E and Z alkenes with good to high selectivity of 2b, 2c, 2d and 2e respectively. Then aliphatic internal alkynes 1f, 1 g and 1 h were easily converted into the respective E and Z alkenes with better selectivity of 2f, 2 g and 2 h respectively. The polarity of alkynes is more than the alkenes, hence the alkynes can interact more with ethylene glycol and alkenes are less polar comes out into the toluene phase which was beneficial for separation of reactant and product. Moreover, we also evaluated the semi-hydrogenation of terminal alkynes with different functional groups as shown in Table 5 . As phenylacetylene (1i) is more reactive than diphenylacetylene (1a) it requires mild reaction conditions: 1i (1 mmol), Ru3(CO)12 (0.01 mmol), TPPTS (0.04 mmol), CO/H2 (10 bar), EG-toluene 1:1 (10 mL), 70 °C, 6 h, 600 rpm. These optimized reaction conditions are used for the substrate study for terminal alkynes. Phenylacetylene containing electron-donating group such as -Me, -OMe, -NMe2, -NH2, -OH (1j-1o) and electron withdrawing group -F (1p) furnished towards respective alkenes with high selectivity (85%–97%) as shown in Table 5. The alkyne with N-heteroatom (1q) could also be easily reduced to 2q with 86% selectivity. Then aliphatic terminal alkynes (1 r, 1 s and 1 t) were successfully provided the product (2 r, 2 s and 2 t) with the 92%, 90% and 80% selectivity respectively. Finally, the propargyl amine (1 u), propargyl alcohol (1v) and propargyl bromide (1 w) were selectively reduced to respective alkenes allyl amine (2 u), allyl alcohol (2v) and allyl bromide (2 w). 4 Catalyst reusability The recyclability study of Ru/TPPTS catalyst was examined for semi-hydrogenation of alkynes under an optimized reaction conditions for method A as shown in Fig. 2 (a) and for method B as shown in Fig. 2(b). An excellent conversion of 1a and excellent selectivity of 2a was observed even after fifth recycle for method and method B. After the completion of reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature. The catalyst was recovered from the reaction mixture was separated by simple decantation process. Biphasic system has two separate phases of ethylene glycol and toluene solvent, upper phase contains untreated substrate and product. The lower phase includes Ru-TPPTS catalyst in ethylene glycol solvent. So as to establish that there was no catalyst leaching, the upper layer was examined for each run by ICP-AES technique. The leaching of ruthenium metal was found as below detectable level from the results obtained by ICP-AES analysis technique. The Ru-TPPTS catalyst for method A and method B was easily separated and it could be recycled up to five consecutive cycles. (Fig. 2) 5 Conclusions In conclusion, we have developed Ru/TPPTS as an efficient and reusable catalytic system for the synthesis of E and Z-alkenes via selective semi-hydrogenation of alkynes using molecular hydrogen and syngas. In the present protocol, used carbon monoxide play a key role to provide E and Z selectivity. The main advantage of this protocol is easy separation of metal catalyst and product. This protocol eliminates the use of poisonous metals, additives, hazardous solvents, co-catalysts and excess amount of chemicals. This developed method tolerates wide range of internal as well as terminal alkynes and affords the respective alkenes with high selectivity. The catalyst could be easily recovered and shows significant recyclability up to the fifth run without loss of its catalytic activity. Acknowledgement The Author SAJ thanks to the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR) India, for providing Senior Research Fellowship (SRF). coredata.dc:description: The chemoselective semi-hydrogenation of alkynes into E and Z-alkenes was studied by using Ru/TPPTS as a biphasic and recyclable catalyst in ethylene glycol-toluene solvent system. Current protocol is atom efficient and gives selectivity up to 98%. This protocol is alternative to the classical Lindlar catalyst (Pd/CaCO3) for Z-alkenes and also Birch reduction process (Li/Na/K in liq. NH3) used for the synthesis of E-alkenes. A variety of alkynes with different functional group can be tolerated efficiently transformed into corresponding E and Z alkenes. This catalytic system has been effectively recycled up to five consecutive cycles without appreciable loss in its activity and selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Semi-hydrogenation of alkynes using Ru/TPPTS as a biphasic recyclable catalyst in ethylene glycol-toluene solvent system
